By J. C. HANDELSMAN
ALL ROADS WITHIN A RADIUS
of 200 miles will lead to the
Hopkins tomorrow, as the ODKsponsored Alumni day, first of its
kind, becomes reality. And the spirit
of goaikikr
with
--tendant back-slapping and handshaking will reign as never before in
Homewood.
On many of the 150 or 200 circular replies received were enthusiastic
remarks. Some went to great length:
". . . wonderful idea, but years too
late in starting . . .," "swell, looking
forward to it." Campus spirit, too,
has indicated that undergraduates
are "looking forward to it."
After the Princeton lacrosse tussle
in the afternoon, at which Dr Shaffer
has asked members of the '28 Olympic
team to sit en the bench, open houses
are to be the order of the day. Lever-

To welcome alumni

Crist plans contest fai June week beauty
queen; M Kempton, Crist, Victoroff to judge
INJECTING A GAY, SURPRISE
element into the coming June week
festivities, Frank Crist, committee
chairman, released the details about
the "First beauty contest in June
week history."
Murray Kempton,
editor of the NEWS-LETTER, Victor M
Victoroff, editor of the Blue Jay
magazine, and Crist will judge the
photographs. Three prizes will be
awarded to the top winners; twenty
others will receive distinction as
"June week queens."
Undergraduates are invited to submit portrait-photos of their best girls
to the contest. All prizes anti the
presentation of the winners will take
place at the Senior ball, June 7, at
the Alcazar ballroom.
All pictures are to be sent to Post
Office Box 1141. The judges suggest

that the instructions "Do Not Fold"
be written on the envelope to insure
the safety of each picture. All entries are deadllned for May 20, at
12:30 p m. It is requested that they
be not larger than 12 by 12 Inches,
nor smaller than postcard size.
The name of the entry, her hometown address, and the name of the
student submitting the entry with
his year must accompany every submitted photograph.
"An advance notice of the contest
which appeared in a week-early issue
of the Blue Jay has already brought
results," announce the judges. They
expect that the girls vying for honors
will represent every fraternity on the
campus, and particularly members of
the graduating clans. Emphasis on
the fact that the photographs will re-

ceive careful handling, and would be
"returned as received" was stressed
by Crist.
News on the bands which will be
signed up for June week was forecasted mysteriously by committee
members as "...the biggest in Hopkir. history"

Dean Edward W. Berry
ing hall has planned an open house
in the Sherwood room, from 5 to 6
p m, when refreshments will be
served. All alumni and their families
are invited, to be met by the Y cabinet.
Delta Upsilon, Phi Psi,
Delta and many of the other Greek
houses have indicated plans for open

Reading period plan
desired, 384 to 32
"IT IS IMPOSSIBLE TO REVIEW.
half a year's work in one night" was
the opinion expressed by the voters
who felt that a pre-examination reading period is essential to a clearer
comprehension of tne examination.
The students upholding this conviction numbered 384; the opposition 32.
However, the intention of the poll
was not to discover the mathematical
status of the problem, but rather the
sentiment behind it. After considering all submitted opinions, it was
found that there were three different
points of view: a reading period
would provide more time for review;
it would be an excellent opportunity
for loafing; the present system offers
adequate time for studying, and the
reading period would precipitate
numerous evils.
The consensus of opinion of the
minority was that students would be
tempted to let their work slip, always
procrastinating at.d anticipating a
week of cramming.

THE DANCE IS OVER, BUT THE
memory lingers on. At least it does
for those people who attended the
Freshman-sophomore dance, held in
the main ballroom of the Belvedere
hotel last Friday night.
Festivities were put into full swing
as soon a* the hands of the clock
pointed to 9:00 p m. In just a little
while the ballroom waz filled with
a mixture of all of the classes at the
•Iopkins. Freshman and sophomore,
hand-in-hand, rubbed shoulders with
junior and senior.
By far the most striking feature
of the affair was the variety of
catchy arrangements included in the
repertoire of the orchestra. Bob
Craig and his boys really outdid
themselves as t'ney swung into copy
arrangements of Chick Webb's "Rock
It For Me," Art Shaw's "Shoot The
Likker To Me, John, Boy," Tommy
Dorsey's "Dipsy Doodle,' and many
others.
And not to forget one of the high
points in the evenings entertainment,
mention must be made of the superlative swing vocals by the charming
Miss Shirley Dewlow. Time and again
requests came in that she repeat "It's
Wonderful," "Stardust," "Rock It
For Me," and a host of other numbers.

for prizes offered in the Music club
raffle was held. The Junior prom

HOMEWOOD BALTIMORE

THE SOPHOMORE CLASS OF
this university will hold its annual
banquet at the Kenmore Inn on Fri•
day evening, May 13.
Plans for the occasion have been
in the making for several weeks, and
the committee, under the chairmanship of Ben Courtwright, has almost
completed all arrangements.
The new plan of compulsory dues
which went into effect at the beginning of this year max„--!.ffect the
sophomores, in regard to price of
tickets for the affair. In past years
the class was not in a position to
finance the banquet from its own
funds, but this year a new situation
may prevail. The committee feels
that there is a possibility that the
affair may be free of charge for
sophomores. At any rate, the tickets
will not cost more than fifty or seventy-five cents.
Besides Ben Courtwright, the following men comprise the remainder
of the Banquet committee: Richard
Green, Felix Ireland, Eugene Mihalyka, Norman Silverstein, and
Robert Vernon.
Similar plans are under way for
the Freshman banquet which will be
held a week or two later than the
sophomore affair.

Crist plans contest fai June week beauty
queen; M Kempton, Crist, Victoroff to judge
INJECTING A GAY, SURPRISE
element into the coming June week
festivities, Frank Crist, committee
chairman, released the details about
the "First beauty contest in June
week history."
Murray Kempton,
editor of the NEWS-LETTER, Victor M
Victoroff, editor of the Blue Jay
magazine, and Crist will judge the
photographs. Three prizes will be
awarded to the top winners; twenty
others will receive distinction as
"June week queens."
Undergraduates are invited to submit portrait-photos of their best girls
to the contest. All prizes anti the
presentation of the winners will take
place at the Senior ball, June 7, at
the Alcazar ballroom.
All pictures are to be sent to Post
Office Box 1141. The judges suggest

that the instructions "Do Not Fold"
be written on the envelope to insure
the safety of each picture. All entries are deadllned for May 20, at
12:30 p m. It is requested that they
be not larger than 12 by 12 Inches,
nor smaller than postcard size.
The name of the entry, her hometown address, and the name of the
student submitting the entry with
his year must accompany every submitted photograph.
"An advance notice of the contest
which appeared in a week-early issue
of the Blue Jay has already brought
results," announce the judges. They
expect that the girls vying for honors
will represent every fraternity on the
campus, and particularly members of
the graduating clans. Emphasis on
the fact that the photographs will re-

ceive careful handling, and would be
"returned as received" was stressed
by Crist.
News on the bands which will be
signed up for June week was forecasted mysteriously by committee
members as "...the biggest in Hopkir. history"

Reading period plan
desired, 384 to 32
"IT IS IMPOSSIBLE TO REVIEW.
half a year's work in one night" was
the opinion expressed by the voters
who felt that a pre-examination reading period is essential to a clearer
comprehension of tne examination.
The students upholding this conviction numbered 384; the opposition 32.
However, the intention of the poll
was not to discover the mathematical
status of the problem, but rather the
sentiment behind it. After considering all submitted opinions, it was
found that there were three different
points of view: a reading period
would provide more time for review;
it would be an excellent opportunity
for loafing; the present system offers
adequate time for studying, and the
reading period would precipitate
numerous evils.
The consensus of opinion of the
minority was that students would be
tempted to let their work slip, always
procrastinating at.d anticipating a
week of cramming.

THE DANCE IS OVER, BUT THE
memory lingers on. At least it does
for those people who attended the
Freshman-sophomore dance, held in
the main ballroom of the Belvedere
hotel last Friday night.
Festivities were put into full swing
as soon a* the hands of the clock
pointed to 9:00 p m. In just a little
while the ballroom waz filled with
a mixture of all of the classes at the
•Iopkins. Freshman and sophomore,
hand-in-hand, rubbed shoulders with
junior and senior.
By far the most striking feature
of the affair was the variety of
catchy arrangements included in the
repertoire of the orchestra. Bob
Craig and his boys really outdid
themselves as t'ney swung into copy
arrangements of Chick Webb's "Rock
It For Me," Art Shaw's "Shoot The
Likker To Me, John, Boy," Tommy
Dorsey's "Dipsy Doodle,' and many
others.
And not to forget one of the high
points in the evenings entertainment,
mention must be made of the superlative swing vocals by the charming
Miss Shirley Dewlow. Time and again
requests came in that she repeat "It's
Wonderful," "Stardust," "Rock It
For Me," and a host of other numbers.
At exactly 12:00 m, the drawing
for prizes offered in the Music club
raffle was held. The Junior prom
ticket went to an unidentified gentle-

HOMEWOOD BALTIMORE

THE SOPHOMORE CLASS OF
this university will hold its annual
banquet at the Kenmore Inn on Fri•
day evening, May 13.
Plans for the occasion have been
in the making for several weeks, and
the committee, under the chairmanship of Ben Courtwright, has almost
completed all arrangements.
The new plan of compulsory dues
which went into effect at the beginning of this year max„--!.ffect the
sophomores, in regard to price of
tickets for the affair. In past years
the class was not in a position to
finance the banquet from its own
funds, but this year a new situation
may prevail. The committee feels
that there is a possibility that the
affair may be free of charge for
sophomores. At any rate, the tickets
will not cost more than fifty or seventy-five cents.
Besides Ben Courtwright, the following men comprise the remainder
of the Banquet committee: Richard
Green, Felix Ireland, Eugene Mihalyka, Norman Silverstein, and
Robert Vernon.
Similar plans are under way for
the Freshman banquet which will be
held a week or two later than the
sophomore affair.
